items.headline: U.S. trade deficit in goods widened sharply in July as firms raced to avoid tariffs
items.summary_en: The U.S. trade deficit in goods widened 22.1% to $103.6 billion in July from $84.9 billion, according to the Commerce Department’s advance estimate released Friday.
items.next_en: Next: watch scheduled data (CPI/Jobs/Fed) or company guidance.

items.headline: Key U.S. inflation gauge creeps higher, but not enough to stave off Fed interest-rate cut
items.summary_en: A key measure of inflation rose in July at a rate that suggests persistent price pressures tied to higher U.S. tariffs, but the increase probably wasn’t big enough to dissuade the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates next month.
items.next_en: Next: watch scheduled data (CPI/Jobs/Fed) or company guidance.

items.headline: Trump closes the ‘de minimis’ shipping loophole. Etsy and eBay shares have tumbled.
items.summary_en: The “de minimis” exemption for shipments worth $800 has ended.

items.headline: My friend, 61, signed a $20K contract for dental implants. She can’t afford it. Can she fight it?
items.summary_en: “After her room and board is paid at the assisted-living home, she has $9,000 left for the year.”

items.headline: Americans spend a lot more on  cars in July, but not much else. Tariffs keep consumers cautious.
items.summary_en: Americans bought more new cars and trucks in July to try to avoid tariff-related price increases, but they spent cautiously on other goods and services amid ongoing turbulence in the U.S. economy.
items.next_en: Next: watch scheduled data (CPI/Jobs/Fed) or company guidance.

items.headline: ‘My blood pressure is sky high’: I’m in my 70s and a widow. I pay $12K a year for long-term-care insurance. Do I cut the cord?
items.summary_en: “What if I become cognitively impaired and need benefits for 15-20 years?”

items.headline: Yes, rate cuts will be good for stocks. But here’s why it means the Fed will be stimulating an economy that doesn’t need it.
items.summary_en: The market wealth effect will boost growth even more, according to Ed Yardeni.

items.headline: I earn $95,000 and have $41,000 in student-loan debt to pay off — but I can’t stop shopping. Help!
items.summary_en: You can be more intentional with how you shop so that you still feel creatively fed and stay on budget. The shift you’ll have to make, though, is more mental than financial.
